comment.shortText: Array extensions.

takes an `array` of elements of object literal type `<T>`, then sorts out any duplicate elements
with respect to a `key`. If `key` is `undefined`,
### Example: object literals of type `<T>`
```
const Values = [
   {id: 1, b: 'first element'},
   {id: 2, b: 'second element'},
   {id: 3, b: 'third element'},
   {id: 1, b: 'first element'},
];

Creates a checksum on a string.
Adapted from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/811195/fast-open-source-checksum-for-small-strings
fast implementation for short strings (20-500 chars)

# Date formatting support.
Formats are specified in a printf-style format string.
## Supported Formats
- `%YY, %YYYY`           : two- or four-digit year, as '73', '1973'
- `%M, %MM, %MMM, %MMMM` : month of year as '2', '02', 'Feb', 'February'
- `%D, %DD`              : day of month as '5', '05' (1...31)
- `%DDD, %DDDD`          : day of week as 'Tue', 'Tuesday'
- `%h, %hh`              : hour of day as '7', '07 (0...23)
- `%m, %mm`              : minutes as '6', '06' (0..59)
- `%ss`                  : seconds as '09' (0...59)
- `%j, %jj, %jjj`        : milliseconds as '1', '15', '159'
short and long weekday names
short and long month names

## Example: 
date('%MM/%DD/%YY');           // -> 08/17/16 (using current date)
let d = new Date('7/4/2010');
date('%DDDD, %MM/%DD/%YY', d); // -> Sunday, 07/04/10
comment.returns: a copy of `formatString` where all supported patterns are replaced by the respective values from `date`.

comment.text: the format string to use.

comment.shortText: add leading zeros to an integer until `digits` are reached
converts minutes, hours, days, weeks ... into milliseconds and back
# Number Formatting Support.
rounds a number `n` to the specified `d` decimals and returns a string

comment.text: the number to round
the number of decimal digits to round to; defaults to 0

comment.shortText:
## Helpful Script Timing Support
Provides convenience functions that don't depend on specific frameworks or libraries

tags.text:
ensures that function calls in a sequence are not executed faster than a preset minimum delay.

**Usage:**
```
const q = new PacingQueue(100); // 100ms between calls
...
q.add((ms) => `I have been called after ${ms}ms`;})
   .then((result) => console.log(result));     // prints: I have been called after ***ms`
```

comment.shortText: the maximum number of concurrent execution calls; defaults to -1 (no limit)

adds the function to the queue. After an appropriate time has passed,
the function will be called with the delay in ms as parameter.
comment.returns: a promise that resolved to the result of the function

tags.text:
delays a promise, passing the parameter
received from the calling promise down to the resolving promise.

**Usage 1:** a delay within the `then` chain:
```
<PromiseLike>
   .then(...)
   .then(delay(10))
   .then(...)
   .catch(...)
```
**Usage 2:** an initial delay
```
delay(10)()
   .then(...)
   .catch(...)
```

comment.shortText:
Sequentially calls the provided `tasks` in a `.then()` chain of promises,
guaranteeing the order of execution per index order in the array.
Each task can return a result, or a promise for a result.
comment.returns: an array of results for each task

comment.text: an array of task calls to execute in sequence. Each call will pass the array of results for tasks so far executed.
optional initial array to collect the task results.
the milliseconds to wait before rejecting

comment.shortText:
Logging convenience functions.
## Usage
main logging class. See {@link log log overview} for usage.
Debug reporting level with importance 0
Warning reporting level with importance 3
Info reporting level with importance 1
Info reporting level with importance 2
current date format string. See [date module]('_date_.html')
current reporting level, same across all modules
the global `log` object.

configures the log facility.
- cfg.colors: boolean, determines if output is colored
- cfg.logfile: sets the naming template for the logfile. Set logFile=null to disable.
- cfg.format: sets the format for the timestamp for each log entry
- cfg.level: sets the reporting level (same as calling log.level())

reports an debug message to the log.
The message will actually be reported to the log only if the current
reporting level is DEBUG or lower.
comment.returns: promise to return the file written to, or undefined

comment.text: the message to report. If msg is an object literal, a deep inspection will be printed.

comment.shortText:
reports an error message to the log.
The message will always be reported to the log.
comment.returns: promise to return the file written to, or undefined

comment.text: the message to report. If msg is an object literal, a deep inspection will be printed.

comment.shortText:
sets the format string to use for logging. If no parameter is specified,
the function returns the currently set format string. The preset is '%YYYY%MM%DD %hh:%mm:%ss.%jjj'
For supported formats see {@link date date}.
Usage
- `format(null)` sets the format to `defDateFormat`
- `format()` returns the current format without changing it.

comment.text: optional format string to use;

comment.shortText:
reports an informational message to the log.
The message will actually be reported to the log only if the current
reporting level is INFO or lower.
comment.returns: promise to return the file written to, or undefined

comment.text: the message to report. If msg is an object literal, a deep inspection will be printed.

comment.shortText:
Usage: `log.info(log.inspect(struct, 1))`
The call returns a raw formatted text string, or a HTML formatted string if `colors` is defined.
comment.returns: a string representation of an object literal, similar to the Node `util.inspect` call

comment.text: depth of recursion, defaults to 3. Use `null` for infinite depth
the indent string to use, will accumulate for each level of indentation, defaults to four spaces.

an array of `css` color values: if defined, the output will be `HTML` formatted, with indentation
levels indicated by colors in ascending sequence from the array, restarting at index 0 if the array is shorter than the maximum indentation level.
`colors` defaults to the static `COLORS` array. To disable, provide a value of `null`.

comment.shortText: sets the reporting level according to `newLevel`. Valid values are {@link log.DEBUG log.DEBUG}, {@link log.INFO log.INFO}, {@link log.WARN log.WARN}, {@link log.ERROR log.ERROR}, or `null`. Subsequent reporting calls will be filtered such that only calls with an importance at least the same as `newLevel` will be written to the log.
comment.text:
By default, `newLevel` sets the reporting level for the module only, and takes precedence over
any global level setting. Providing `null` as level value passes precedence back to the global setting.
This allows for simple per-module settings, for example in debugging scenarios.
comment.returns: the new reporting level (DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR)

comment.text:
the new reporting level to set.
If omitted, the method returns the currently set reporting level.
If set to `null`, the module's local reporting level defaults to the global reporting level; `setGlobalLevel` is ignored.
defaults to `false`. If `true`, sets the global reporting level for all modules.

comment.shortText:
Creates the core format of the reported message. This method is
called within `out` to allow for format extensions of the message printed,
e.g. by color codes.

reports an error message to the log.
The message will be reported to the log if `lvl` meets or exceeds the current reporting level.
comment.returns: promise to return the message written

comment.text: the reporting level of `msg`
the message to report. If msg is an object literal, a deep inspection will be printed.

comment.shortText: defines a prefix to be printed for each call to a log function.

comment.text: the prefix to prepend. Defaults to '';

comment.shortText:
reports an warning message to the log.
The message will actually be reported to the log only if the current
reporting level is WARN or lower.
comment.returns: promise to return the file written to, or undefined

comment.text: the message to report. If msg is an object literal, a deep inspection will be printed.

# hsUtil
comment.text: Helpful Scripts utility functions for use in both browser and `node` environments [Coverage Info] [![npm version](https://badge.fury.io/js/hsutil.svg)](https://badge.fury.io/js/hsutil) [![GitHub](https://img.shields.io/badge/GitHub-hsUtil-blue.svg)](https://github.com/helpfulscripts/hsutil) [![docs](https://img.shields.io/badge/hsDocs-hsUtil-blue.svg)](https://helpfulscripts.github.io/hsUtil/#!/api/hsUtil/0) [![Build Status](https://travis-ci.org/HelpfulScripts/hsUtil.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/HelpfulScripts/hsUtil) [![Dependencies Status](https://david-dm.org/helpfulscripts/hsutil.svg)](https://david-dm.org/helpfulscripts/hsutil) [![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/repos/github/HelpfulScripts/hsUtil/badge.svg)](https://coveralls.io/github/HelpfulScripts/hsUtil) [![Known Vulnerabilities](https://snyk.io/test/github/HelpfulScripts/hsUtil/badge.svg?targetFile=package.json)](https://snyk.io/test/github/HelpfulScripts/hsUtil?targetFile=package.json) [![NPM License](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-brightgreen.svg)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hsutil) ___ ## Index - no external dependencies: -   {@link TimedPromises TimedPromises} functions that provide delays and timeouts for promises. -   {@link Checksum Checksum} a quick checksum implementation for small strings -   {@link Date Date} printf-style date formatting function -   {@link round Number.round} rounding to n digits -   {@link log Log} module-level logging
